title: Rome — The Dome of All Things
teaser: An emperor who designs buildings, a former slave who teaches philosophy, and biographers who invent the Western art of the life story. The Roman Empire at its zenith builds a temple open to the sky — and a Stoicism that will outlast the empire itself.

art.label: Art
art.content: The Pantheon, rebuilt under Hadrian between c. 118 and 128 CE, is the supreme achievement of Roman imperial architecture — and arguably the most influential building in Western history. Its unreinforced concrete dome, 43.3 metres in diameter, would remain the largest in the world for over thirteen centuries until Brunelleschi's in Florence (1436). The oculus — a 9-metre opening to the sky — is the sole light source, turning the interior into a sundial where weather and cosmos enter the built space. According to Cassius Dio, Hadrian personally designed the building, rejecting the plans of Trajan's architect Apollodorus of Damascus. At Hadrian's Villa in Tivoli (c. 118–134), the emperor created a vast architectural anthology — recreating buildings from across the empire: the Canopus of Egypt, the Stoa Poikile of Athens, the Vale of Tempe. It is architecture as imperial memory, a built encyclopedia of the cultures Rome had absorbed. Meanwhile, after Hadrian's beloved Antinous drowned in the Nile in 130 CE, the emperor commissioned what became the most widely reproduced portrait type of the ancient world — more surviving statues of Antinous than of almost any other figure from antiquity.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Plutarch (d. c. 119 CE) had just completed his Parallel Lives — forty-six biographies pairing a Greek statesman with a Roman one (Theseus with Romulus, Alexander with Caesar), inventing the method of comparative biography that would shape life-writing through Shakespeare to Napoleon. Suetonius (c. 69–122 CE), who served as Hadrian's ab epistulis (secretary of correspondence) until being dismissed around 122, published The Twelve Caesars with its scandalous access to imperial archives — biography as revelation of private character behind public power. Juvenal (active c. 100–127) was writing his later Satires, perfecting the tradition of Roman verse satire — the genre Rome considered its own invention (satura tota nostra est, as Quintilian claimed). His phrase panem et circenses (bread and circuses) would become the permanent shorthand for political appeasement. This was also the era of the Second Sophistic — a Greek literary revival under Roman rule, championed by Hadrian's philhellenism, where rhetoricians like Favorinus performed elaborate orations as both entertainment and intellectual display.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Epictetus (c. 50–135 CE), a former slave who had been crippled by his master, taught late Stoicism at his school in Nicopolis, in north-western Greece. His student Arrian — who was simultaneously a Roman consul, military commander, and historian — transcribed his oral teachings as the Discourses and distilled them into the Enchiridion (Handbook). The core doctrine: the only things truly within our control are our judgements and choices; everything external — health, wealth, reputation, even the body — belongs to fortune. This is philosophy as practice rather than theory, a discipline of inner freedom developed by a man who had known literal slavery. The transmission chain is documented precisely: Marcus Aurelius, writing his Meditations fifty years later, names Epictetus among his greatest intellectual debts (Book I) — the Stoic teachings of a freed slave reaching the most powerful man on earth through Arrian's pen.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Roman Empire under Hadrian (r. 117–138 CE) stood at its administrative and demographic zenith — roughly 55 to 70 million people across three continents, governed by a road network of 80,000 kilometres and a professional bureaucracy. Hadrian reversed the expansionist policy of his predecessor Trajan, withdrawing from Mesopotamia and consolidating borders. Hadrian's Wall in Britain (begun 122 CE) embodied this shift from conquest to consolidation — not a fortress wall but a controlled frontier, managing movement rather than stopping it. This was the age of the Five Good Emperors (Nerva through Marcus Aurelius), the period that Gibbon would later call "the period in the history of the world during which the condition of the human race was most happy and prosperous" — a judgement that excluded the empire's millions of slaves, but captured the administrative stability of the Pax Romana at its peak.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: The documented links here run through specific people and institutions. Suetonius served as Hadrian's personal secretary until c. 122, giving the biographer direct access to the imperial archives he mined for The Twelve Caesars — the historian was literally inside the power he described. Arrian, who transcribed Epictetus's teachings, was no mere scribe but a Roman consul and provincial governor — the same imperial administrative class that built the Pantheon consumed and transmitted Stoic philosophy. Hadrian himself was the nexus: an emperor who personally designed the Pantheon (per Cassius Dio), championed Greek literary culture through the Second Sophistic, and created in his Villa at Tivoli a built synthesis of the empire's absorbed civilisations. Plutarch's Parallel Lives, comparing Greek and Roman exemplars, provided the intellectual framework for exactly this Greco-Roman synthesis that Hadrian pursued architecturally and politically. The Pantheon's mathematical perfection — its height equalling its diameter, its dome a perfect hemisphere — was not accidental ornament but a statement legible to a culture steeped in Stoic cosmology, where the universe was understood as rationally ordered.
conn.funFact: Hadrian kept the original inscription crediting Agrippa — "M·AGRIPPA·L·F·COS·TERTIVM·FECIT" — on the façade of his entirely rebuilt Pantheon. For centuries, scholars assumed Agrippa's building had survived. Only modern brick-stamp analysis proved the entire structure is Hadrian's. An emperor who hid his masterpiece behind another man's name.

title: Baghdad — The Round City of Reason
teaser: A caliph builds a perfect circle in the desert. Inside it, Greek philosophy meets Arab poetry and Persian administration — the Islamic Golden Age ignites.

art.label: Art
art.content: Early Abbasid art fuses Umayyad, Persian, and Central Asian traditions into something new — a cosmopolitan visual language for a cosmopolitan empire. Al-Mansur's Round City itself is the masterpiece: a perfect circle nearly 2 km across, with the caliph's palace and grand mosque at the centre — geometry as theology, power radiating outward from a divine axis. The aniconism of Islamic art channels creative energy into breathtaking arabesque patterns and calligraphy, transforming the written word itself into visual art.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Arabic poetry enters its most inventive phase. The Abbasid revolution shifts literary patronage from Damascus to Iraq, and poets begin breaking the rigid pre-Islamic qasida form. A generation of muhdath ("modern") poets is emerging — figures like Abu Nuwas (born c. 756) will soon scandalise Baghdad with wine poems that mock Bedouin nostalgia and celebrate urban Persian cosmopolitanism. The translation movement is beginning: Greek, Syriac, Sanskrit, and Persian texts are being rendered into Arabic, creating the largest body of translated knowledge the ancient world had seen.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: The Mu'tazila, founded by Wasil ibn Ata (d. 748), are the first systematic school of Islamic rationalist theology (kalam) — arguing that reason, not tradition alone, can determine truth. Their insistence on divine justice and human free will directly challenges fatalist interpretations of the Quran. Under the Abbasids, the Mu'tazila gain state patronage — an extraordinary moment when a government officially endorses rational inquiry as the path to religious truth. Meanwhile, the translation of Aristotle into Arabic is just beginning, laying the groundwork for falsafa (Islamic philosophy proper).

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Abbasid Revolution (750) overthrows the Umayyads in one of history's great political ruptures — a coalition of Persian converts, Shia sympathisers, and discontented frontier armies united under the black banners. Al-Mansur founds Baghdad in 762 as a deliberate break from the old Umayyad capital Damascus, placing power at the crossroads of Persian, Mesopotamian, and Arab worlds. In 751, the Battle of Talas against Tang China halts Chinese expansion westward and — according to tradition — brings papermaking technology to the Islamic world, revolutionising scholarship.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Everything converges on translation as power. The Abbasids legitimise their rule not through Arab tribal prestige (as the Umayyads did) but through universal knowledge — Persian administration, Greek science, Indian mathematics, all filtered through Arabic. The Round City's perfect geometry embodies the Mu'tazila's rationalism: both insist the cosmos is orderly and knowable. Poetry's break from Bedouin forms mirrors the political break from Umayyad tribalism. When Abu Nuwas praises wine in Persian-inflected Arabic, he's enacting the same cultural synthesis that the House of Wisdom will soon institutionalise.
conn.funFact: Al-Mansur reportedly chose Baghdad's site after sleeping a night there and finding it pleasant. He allegedly consulted astrologers who confirmed the stars favoured the location — reason and superstition coexisting, as they so often did in the Age of Reason's first draft.

image.caption: Plan of al-Mansur's Round City of Baghdad

title: Florence — The Beautiful Catastrophe
teaser: A third of Europe dies. From the ashes, Boccaccio writes in the vernacular, painters discover the skull beneath the skin, and philosophy learns to cut with a razor.

art.label: Art
art.content: The Triumph of Death becomes Europe's defining image. The anonymous Palermo fresco (c. 1446, but rooted in the iconography born now) shows Death on a skeletal horse trampling nobles and clergy alike — democracy through annihilation. The danse macabre tradition emerges: paintings and murals in churches and cemeteries depicting the living dancing with their own corpses, pope alongside peasant. This is something new — art as memento mori at civilisational scale. In Siena, Ambrogio Lorenzetti (d. 1348) has just completed his Allegory of Good and Bad Government, the first great secular fresco cycle; the plague kills him and halts Sienese painting for a generation. Art turns inward, devotional, haunted.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Boccaccio's Decameron (written 1348–1353) frames a hundred stories inside the plague itself: ten young Florentines flee to the countryside and tell tales to hold death at bay. It's literature as survival — and the first great prose masterpiece in vernacular Italian, proving that the language of the streets can carry the weight of Ovid and Apuleius. Petrarch, who loses his beloved Laura to the plague in April 1348, transforms private grief into the Canzoniere's second half — the poems in morte di Madonna Laura become the template for European love poetry for three centuries. Both writers are doing something radical: choosing Italian and the personal voice over Latin and scholastic authority.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: William of Ockham (d. 1347) dies this very year, likely of plague, leaving behind the most powerful philosophical weapon of the late Middle Ages: nominalism. His razor — entities must not be multiplied beyond necessity — demolishes the Scholastic apparatus of universals, essences, and invisible categories. Only particulars are real; everything else is a name we give them. This is a depth charge under medieval metaphysics. Combined with the plague's brutal empirical lesson that no amount of theology stops people from dying, nominalism opens a crack that will widen into the Renaissance, the Reformation, and eventually modern science.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Black Death arrives in Sicily in October 1347, carried by Genoese ships from the Crimean port of Caffa (where the Mongols allegedly catapulted infected corpses over the walls — history's first biological weapon). By 1351, it has killed between a third and half of Europe's population — perhaps 25 million people. Florence drops from 120,000 to 50,000. The social order cracks: the Flagellant movement sweeps Germany, mobs massacre Jewish communities across the Rhineland, the Church's authority wobbles as prayers prove useless. But the survivors inherit a transformed economy — labour is scarce, wages rise, serfdom weakens. The catastrophe seeds the conditions for everything that comes after.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Ockham's razor and the plague deliver the same message from different directions: the old abstractions don't hold. Scholasticism said universals were real; Ockham says only individuals exist. The Church said God's order was legible; the plague makes it illegible. Boccaccio's storytellers don't pray — they narrate, replacing theology with human wit. Petrarch mourns Laura not as a Platonic symbol but as a specific, irreplaceable person. The danse macabre paintings democratise death the same way the plague democratises it: no one is exempt. All of this — nominalism, vernacular literature, the crisis of Church authority — points directly toward the Renaissance humanism that will flower 150 years later in the same Florentine streets.
conn.funFact: Boccaccio's Decameron contains a story (VI.10) where a friar passes off a parrot's feather as the Angel Gabriel's — mocking relic fraud. Within a generation of the plague, the Church's monopoly on truth was already being laughed at in prose.

title: Florence — The Duel of Giants
teaser: Michelangelo and Leonardo compete for the same wall. The Renaissance peaks.

art.label: Art
art.content: The High Renaissance reaches its apex — the movement that fused humanist ideals with technical mastery, believing art could reveal divine truth through the study of nature and anatomy. Leonardo and Michelangelo are both commissioned to paint opposing walls of Florence's Sala del Cinquecento. Neither finishes — but the rivalry embodies the Renaissance ideal of paragone, the competitive comparison of arts. Meanwhile Michelangelo's David is unveiled and Raphael, just 21, arrives to absorb both masters' techniques.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Renaissance humanism has transformed literature from medieval allegory into direct engagement with classical models and political reality. Machiavelli, serving as Florence's Second Chancellor, is watching Cesare Borgia's statecraft firsthand — raw material for The Prince (1513), which will break with the humanist tradition of idealised rulers. Ariosto drafts Orlando Furioso in Ferrara, fusing medieval romance with Renaissance irony — the chivalric tradition made self-aware.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Neoplatonism, revived by Marsilio Ficino's translations of Plato, dominates Florentine thought — the idea that beauty reveals divine truth is taken literally, making art and philosophy inseparable. Erasmus publishes Enchiridion militis Christiani, arguing for inner philosophical Christianity over empty ritual — part of Christian humanism, which applies Renaissance textual criticism to religion itself. Both currents reject medieval scholasticism for something more direct and human.

hist.label: History
hist.content: Italy is fractured among warring city-states while France and Spain fight over Naples — the Italian Wars (1494–1559) are turning the peninsula into Europe's battlefield. Florence, recently freed from Savonarola's theocratic rule (burned 1498), is a fragile republic. Globally, the Age of Exploration is reshaping the world: Columbus has made his fourth voyage, Portugal expands in the Indian Ocean, and Europe's centre of gravity is shifting from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Machiavelli watches power while Leonardo and Michelangelo depict it — on the same walls. The Renaissance's unity of knowledge means the diplomat, the painter, and the philosopher all inhabit the same intellectual world. Neoplatonism and Christian humanism are two faces of the same rejection of medieval authority: both insist on going back to original sources — whether Plato or Scripture. The David isn't just sculpture; it's a political statement: the small republic standing against giants, classical form serving civic ideology.
conn.funFact: When the committee chose where to place the David, Leonardo and Botticelli were both on the panel. Leonardo suggested hiding it in a loggia. He was outvoted.

image.caption: Michelangelo's David (1501–1504), Galleria dell'Accademia, Florence

title: Münster — The Exhaustion of God
teaser: Thirty years of religious war end in a radical idea: states, not God, determine order. Meanwhile, in Amsterdam, Rembrandt paints light like a philosopher and Descartes thinks in a country that lets him.

art.label: Art
art.content: The Baroque dominates — art as overwhelming sensory experience, born from the Counter-Reformation's need to seduce believers back through spectacle. But in the Dutch Republic, Baroque takes a Protestant turn: no altarpieces, no papal commissions. Instead, Rembrandt paints civic militias, anatomy lessons, and his own aging face with a chiaroscuro that treats light as moral inquiry. His Night Watch (1642) transformed the group portrait from stiff ceremony into dynamic theatre. Vermeer is eight years from his first masterpiece; the Dutch Golden Age channels its wealth not into cathedrals but into domestic interiors, still lifes, and landscapes — the everyday made luminous.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: The war breeds its own literature of devastation. Grimmelshausen's Simplicissimus (1668, but rooted in this decade's experience) will become the great German picaresque — a naïve boy dragged through three decades of atrocity, the Thirty Years' War as anti-Bildungsroman. In England, Milton is already formulating Paradise Lost, the Baroque epic that turns Satan into literature's first complex villain. Corneille and Racine are forging French Classicism — tragedy governed by strict unities, reason imposing form on passion. Order as aesthetic, because the world offers none.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Descartes, living in the Dutch Republic precisely because it tolerates free thought, has already published the Meditations (1641) and the Principles of Philosophy (1644) — the founding texts of Continental Rationalism. His method of radical doubt (cogito ergo sum) rebuilds knowledge from a single certainty, discarding all inherited authority. In Amsterdam, the young Spinoza is absorbing Descartes while preparing to surpass him — his Ethics will fuse God and Nature into one substance, eliminating the personal God that thirty years of war were fought over.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Peace of Westphalia ends both the Thirty Years' War and the Eighty Years' War, redrawing Europe around a revolutionary principle: state sovereignty. Each ruler determines their territory's religion (cuius regio, eius religio), and no power — not the Pope, not the Emperor — may intervene in another state's affairs. Germany has lost perhaps a third of its population; some regions, over half. The Dutch Republic gains formal independence from Spain and enters its golden age — a commercial empire built on tolerance, trade, and the world's first stock exchange.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Descartes' method and the Westphalian settlement perform the same operation: they replace divine authority with human reason as the foundation of order. The philosopher doubts everything and rebuilds from the cogito; the diplomats doubt religious truth and rebuild from sovereignty. Dutch painting enacts this too — Rembrandt's light doesn't descend from heaven, it falls from a window, natural and specific. The Baroque's Catholic theatricality and Dutch Protestant restraint are twin responses to the same crisis: how do you make meaning after God has been weaponised?
conn.funFact: Descartes died in 1650 after moving to Sweden at Queen Christina's invitation. He was required to give philosophy lessons at 5 AM in a freezing palace. The rationalist who rebuilt all knowledge from first principles was defeated by a Scandinavian winter.

image.caption: Rembrandt van Rijn, The Night Watch (1642), Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam

title: Europe — Dare to Know
teaser: In Königsberg, Kant dares humanity to think for itself. In Paris, a servant outwits his master on stage and a painter resurrects republican Rome. The Enlightenment finds its voice — five years before the guillotine gives it teeth.

art.label: Art
art.content: Jacques-Louis David is in Rome, painting the work that will remake European art. The Oath of the Horatii (completed 1784, exhibited at the Paris Salon 1785) stages three brothers swearing to die for the Roman Republic — rigid, muscular, geometric, the antithesis of Rococo's languid curves. David's Neoclassicism isn't nostalgia: it's a political weapon, using antiquity to indict the present. The painting's stark tripartite composition — men on the left reaching for swords, grieving women on the right, the father's outstretched arm at the axis — is rationalism made visible: clarity, duty, structure. When it reaches Paris, the crowds understand instantly. This is what virtue looks like. Five years later, David will paint the Revolution itself.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Beaumarchais' The Marriage of Figaro premieres in Paris on 27 April 1784, after three years of royal censorship — Louis XVI reportedly said it would be "dangerous" to perform. He was right. The play is the pinnacle of Enlightenment satirical comedy, a tradition running from Molière through Voltaire's contes: using wit and laughter to expose power's absurdities. Figaro, a servant, outmanoeuvres, outwits, and publicly humiliates his aristocratic master. The fifth-act monologue is a bomb: "What have you done to deserve such advantages? Put yourself to the trouble of being born — nothing more." Danton will later say the play "killed off the nobility"; Napoleon will call it "the Revolution already in action." Meanwhile in Germany, Schiller's Kabale und Liebe (Intrigue and Love) premieres — a defining work of Sturm und Drang, the proto-Romantic movement reacting against Enlightenment rationalism by foregrounding raw emotion and individual subjectivity. Schiller turns the movement's intensity toward class politics: a doomed cross-class love affair crushed by aristocratic corruption.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: In December 1784, the Berlinische Monatsschrift publishes Immanuel Kant's answer to the question that defines the age: "Was ist Aufklärung?" — "What is Enlightenment?" His answer is a single Latin phrase that becomes a civilisational motto: Sapere aude — "Dare to know." Enlightenment, Kant writes, is humanity's emergence from its "self-incurred immaturity" — the inability to use one's own understanding without another's guidance. The obstacle isn't stupidity but cowardice: it is comfortable to let others think for you. Three years earlier, his Critique of Pure Reason (1781) had already demolished the old metaphysics, drawing the precise boundary between what reason can and cannot reach. Now he draws the political consequence: think for yourself, in public, without fear.

hist.label: History
hist.content: Europe in 1784 is a powder keg with a lit fuse. The American Revolution has just succeeded — the Treaty of Paris (1783) confirms it — and French officers who fought there return home full of republican ideals and empty treasury receipts. France's debt from financing American independence is catastrophic; within five years, Louis XVI will be forced to convene the Estates-General. Frederick the Great still rules Prussia, Europe's model "enlightened despot" — tolerant of religion, patron of Voltaire, yet absolute in power. Joseph II of Austria is abolishing serfdom and closing monasteries. The old order is reforming itself frantically, trying to modernise fast enough to survive. It won't be fast enough.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: The most concrete link runs through Paris: David exhibited at the Salon where Beaumarchais' audiences gathered; both operated within a Parisian cultural milieu that shared patrons, salons, and the Académie. The Comte d'Angiviller, Directeur des Bâtiments du Roi, commissioned David's painting as part of a programme of morally elevating history painting — the same state apparatus that had tried and failed to suppress Figaro. Kant in Königsberg and Schiller in Mannheim operated independently of this Parisian world — there is no documented correspondence between any of these four in 1784. What connects them is not mutual influence but a shared historical condition: the late Enlightenment's crisis of legitimacy, as aristocratic authority crumbled under its own contradictions across Europe simultaneously. The American Revolution (Treaty of Paris, 1783) had just demonstrated that Enlightenment ideas could topple an empire — and France, bankrupt from financing it, was five years from proving the point at home.
conn.funFact: Kant never travelled more than about ten miles from Königsberg in his entire life — yet his essay on Enlightenment, written from that provincial Prussian city, became the defining text of a movement that transformed the planet. The citizens of Königsberg reportedly set their clocks by his daily walk. Reason, apparently, keeps excellent time.

title: Paris — The Year Everything Changed
teaser: The Eiffel Tower rises. Van Gogh paints Starry Night. Nietzsche collapses. Bergson rethinks time itself.

art.label: Art
art.content: Post-Impressionism is shattering Impressionism's consensus — where Monet captured light, the next generation wants to capture meaning. Van Gogh paints The Starry Night from the asylum at Saint-Rémy, pushing toward Expressionism: inner feeling over observed fact. Gauguin in Brittany paints The Yellow Christ, part of Symbolism's revolt against realism. Cézanne in Aix quietly bridges Impressionism and Cubism — the most consequential painter alive, though almost no one knows it yet.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Literature is splitting between Naturalism and its discontents. Maupassant publishes Fort comme la mort — Naturalism's clinical gaze turned inward before syphilis claims his mind. Yeats releases The Wanderings of Oisin, launching the Celtic Revival: mythology as resistance to British cultural dominance. Twain's A Connecticut Yankee uses time-travel satire in the tradition of American realism. Tolstoy's Kreutzer Sonata, banned for sexual frankness, signals his turn from novelist to moral prophet.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Nietzsche collapses in Turin in January — his productive life ends. Twilight of the Idols, published this year, is the climax of his assault on Western metaphysics: God is dead, morality is genealogy, truth is interpretation. Bergson publishes Time and Free Will, founding process philosophy: lived time (durée) is fundamentally different from clock time. Both are responding to the crisis of positivism — the feeling that science explains everything except what matters most.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Eiffel Tower opens for the World's Fair celebrating the Revolution's centennial — engineering as ideology, the Second Industrial Revolution made vertical. Brazil becomes a republic. The Meiji Constitution takes effect in Japan — modernisation by imperial decree. London's dock strike marks a turning point for organised labour. The Scramble for Africa is in full swing, carving a continent into European possessions.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Bergson's insight that lived time ≠ measured time is exactly what the Post-Impressionists are painting: Van Gogh doesn't show what the sky looks like, he shows what it feels like. Nietzsche's death-of-God and Van Gogh's asylum visions share the same vertigo — old certainties dissolving into energy. The Eiffel Tower embodies the era's central tension: is modernity liberation or monstrosity? Maupassant famously ate in the Tower's restaurant because "it's the only place in Paris where you can't see the damn thing."
conn.funFact: Theo van Gogh tried to sell Vincent's paintings at the 1889 World's Fair. Almost no one bought. A century later, those paintings would sell for $80+ million each.

image.caption: Vincent van Gogh, The Starry Night (1889), MoMA, New York
image.attribution: Google Art Project, Public Domain, via Wikimedia Commons

title: The Modernist Explosion
teaser: Joyce, Eliot, Woolf, Wittgenstein — in a single year, the old world of art and thought is detonated.

art.label: Art
art.content: The Bauhaus is in full swing under Gropius — Klee, Kandinsky, Moholy-Nagy teaching the radical idea that art, craft, and industry should merge. It's the institutional arm of Constructivism and De Stijl: strip art to pure form, then rebuild the world. Mondrian pushes into geometric abstraction. In Mexico, Rivera begins his first major mural — Mexican Muralism insists art must be public, political, and monumental, not locked in galleries.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: The greatest year in literary Modernism. Joyce's Ulysses (published in Paris, banned in the US/UK) detonates narrative form — the novel as total experiment. Eliot's The Waste Land does the same for poetry: fragments shored against ruins. Woolf's Jacob's Room pioneers stream-of-consciousness. Proust dies in November, In Search of Lost Time unfinished. Rilke completes the Duino Elegies in a single burst. All are responding to WWI's destruction of 19th-century certainties.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Wittgenstein's Tractatus appears in English — the founding text of logical positivism, arguing philosophy's problems are really problems of language. The Vienna Circle is forming around Schlick, taking Wittgenstein further than he intended. Heidegger lectures at Freiburg, developing existential phenomenology — the opposite pole, insisting that Being, not logic, is philosophy's proper subject. The discipline is splitting into two traditions that still haven't reconciled.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Soviet Union is formally established — the Bolshevik experiment becomes a state. Mussolini marches on Rome — fascism takes power for the first time. The Ottoman Empire collapses; Turkey becomes a republic under Atatürk. Tutankhamun's tomb is discovered. The world is four years past WWI, and the interwar order is already fracturing between communism, fascism, and liberal democracy — the three-way struggle that will define the century.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Everything connects through fragmentation. Eliot's Waste Land is literally fragments. Joyce fragments narrative into a dozen styles. The Bauhaus fragments art into geometry. Wittgenstein fragments language into logical atoms. Why? Because the war fragmented everything — empires, bodies, certainties. Modernism isn't a style; it's the art of a shattered world trying to reassemble itself. Proust dies trying to capture all of time; Wittgenstein insists we stay silent about what we can't capture. Two responses to the same impossibility.
conn.funFact: Ezra Pound edited The Waste Land so ruthlessly he cut it nearly in half. The original draft, found in 1968, suggests Pound may have been the greatest editor in literary history.

title: Wittenberg — The Hammer Falls
teaser: A monk nails theses to a church door. In Rome, Raphael paints philosophy. In London, More imagines utopia. The Renaissance synthesis of faith and reason is about to shatter — the Reformation begins.

art.label: Art
art.content: The High Renaissance reaches its culmination in Rome. Raphael has just finished the Stanza della Segnatura (1509–1511) — his School of Athens places Plato and Aristotle at the centre of a temple of philosophy, surrounded by every great thinker from Pythagoras to Averroes. It is the visual manifesto of Renaissance synthesis: the belief that pagan wisdom and Christian truth form a single harmonious system. Now Raphael works on the Stanza dell'Incendio (1514–1517) for Pope Leo X. In Florence, Andrea del Sarto develops the sfumato technique toward what will become Mannerism — the first cracks in High Renaissance confidence. North of the Alps, Dürer has returned from Italy to Nuremberg, bringing Renaissance forms to German art while retaining Northern intensity.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Thomas More's Utopia (1516) invents a genre and a word. Written in Latin for the European humanist elite, it describes an island society with no private property, religious tolerance, and six-hour workdays — Renaissance humanism pushed to its logical political conclusion. More's friend Erasmus, the most celebrated scholar in Europe, has just published his Novum Instrumentum (1516), a critical Greek edition of the New Testament that reveals translation errors in the Vulgate — Christian humanism applying philological method to Scripture itself. In Ferrara, Ariosto's Orlando Furioso (first edition 1516) transforms medieval chivalric romance into Renaissance irony — a 38,000-line epic that treats heroic ideals with sophisticated self-awareness.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: On October 31, 1517, Martin Luther posts his Ninety-five Theses on the door of the Castle Church in Wittenberg — a standard academic invitation to debate. The target is indulgences: the papal practice of selling remission of punishment for sins. But the implications run deeper: Luther's theses attack the very foundation of papal authority over salvation. Within weeks, the printing press transforms a local academic dispute into a European conflagration. Erasmus, who shares Luther's critique of Church corruption but not his theological radicalism, watches the humanist project of gradual reform overtaken by revolution. The Christian humanist synthesis — faith improved by learning, Scripture clarified by scholarship — is about to fracture into Protestant and Catholic camps that will spend the next century killing each other.

hist.label: History
hist.content: Pope Leo X — Giovanni de' Medici, patron of Raphael and embodiment of Renaissance papal splendour — presides over a Church whose corruption is funding the arts. The indulgence that triggers Luther's protest finances the construction of St Peter's Basilica. The Ottoman Empire under Selim I conquers Egypt (1517), absorbing the Mamluk Sultanate and doubling its territory. Charles V is about to inherit an empire spanning from Austria to the Americas. The printing press, now sixty years old, has created something unprecedented: a European public sphere where ideas can spread faster than authorities can suppress them.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: The documented connections centre on Erasmus, who links every dimension. He corresponded with Thomas More (they were close friends; More's Utopia was conceived during Erasmus's 1515 visit to England); his Greek New Testament provided the textual ammunition Luther would use against papal authority; his Praise of Folly (1511), written in More's house, satirised the same Church abuses Luther attacked. Leo X patronised both Raphael and the indulgence-seller Johann Tetzel. The School of Athens and the Ninety-five Theses share a premise — that ancient wisdom illuminates truth — but draw opposite conclusions: Raphael shows philosophy and Christianity in harmony; Luther insists Scripture alone (sola scriptura) judges tradition. The same printing technology that spread More's Utopia across humanist networks spread Luther's theses across Germany in two weeks. Renaissance and Reformation are not opposites — the second is the first pushed past its breaking point.
conn.funFact: Luther may not have actually nailed anything to the door — the hammer story first appears 30 years later. What's documented is that he sent the theses to Archbishop Albrecht. Either way, the printing press did the real work: 300,000 copies were in circulation within three years.

title: London — The Gravity of Reason
teaser: Newton publishes the Principia. Halley funds it. Locke flees to Amsterdam. The composer Lully dies from a conducting wound. A cannon-shot destroys the Parthenon. The Scientific Revolution reaches its crescendo — and a new world clicks into place.

art.label: Art
art.content: The late Baroque dominates European courts, but England is forging something different. Christopher Wren is mid-construction on St Paul's Cathedral (1675–1711), the masterpiece of English Baroque — rational, restrained geometry where Continental Baroque would have swirled. Wren, who was first a mathematician and astronomer (Savilian Professor at Oxford), designs architecture the way Newton designs cosmology: from first principles, subordinating ornament to structure. In Paris, Jean-Baptiste Lully — the Italian-born composer who dominated French music for thirty years — dies in March from gangrene after striking his foot with his conducting staff during a Te Deum. The Baroque spectacle literally kills its greatest impresario. Meanwhile, in Athens, a cannon-shot from Venetian forces besieging the Ottoman-held city hits the Parthenon, which the Turks were using as a gunpowder magazine. The explosion on 26 September 1687 destroys much of the building that had stood intact for 2,100 years — antiquity sacrificed to modern warfare.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Bernard le Bovier de Fontenelle has just published Entretiens sur la pluralité des mondes (1686), the first great work of science popularisation — explaining Copernican cosmology through witty dialogues with a fictional marquise. It makes heliocentrism fashionable, comprehensible, and — crucially — entertaining for the educated public. In 1687 he publishes Histoire des oracles, attacking superstition through historical analysis. Fontenelle, who will live to 99, bridges the age of Corneille (his uncle) to Voltaire — the Enlightenment's first herald. In England, John Dryden remains Poet Laureate, the master of Restoration literature, but his The Hind and the Panther (1687), defending his conversion to Catholicism, appears just as the political ground shifts beneath him. The Glorious Revolution next year will cost him his position. Aphra Behn, the first professional woman writer in English, publishes The Lucky Chance — her stage comedies fund her independence.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: On 5 July 1687, Isaac Newton's Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica is published — the founding text of modern physics and arguably the most important scientific work ever written. In three books, Newton demonstrates that a single mathematical law — the inverse-square law of gravitational attraction — explains the motion of planets, moons, comets, tides, and falling apples. The universe becomes a machine governed by equations. Edmond Halley personally financed the publication (the Royal Society's funds were exhausted on a fish book) and oversaw its printing. Meanwhile, Newton's rival Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz has independently invented calculus and is developing his monadology — the metaphysical alternative to Newtonian mechanism, arguing that the universe consists of irreducible mental units rather than dead matter in motion. John Locke, in exile in Amsterdam fleeing Stuart persecution, is drafting his Essay Concerning Human Understanding — the empiricist counterpart to Newton's physics, arguing that all knowledge derives from sensory experience.

hist.label: History
hist.content: Europe teeters between absolutism and revolution. In France, Louis XIV has revoked the Edict of Nantes (1685), driving 200,000–400,000 Huguenots into exile — Protestant refugees flood into England, the Dutch Republic, Prussia, and the American colonies, carrying skills and capital. In England, James II pushes Catholic toleration against a Protestant establishment that will not tolerate it; the Invitation to William is being drafted, and within eighteen months the Glorious Revolution will depose him without a shot. The Ottoman Empire is in retreat: the failed siege of Vienna (1683) has shifted the balance, and the Holy League — Austria, Poland, Venice, the Papacy — is rolling back Ottoman territory across Hungary and Greece. It's in this campaign that Venice destroys the Parthenon.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: The connections run through the Royal Society and personal networks. Newton, Halley, Wren, and Locke all belonged to the Royal Society — the institutional centre of the Scientific Revolution in England. Halley visited Newton in Cambridge in August 1684, asked him what curve a planet would describe under an inverse-square law, and Newton replied immediately: an ellipse. That visit triggered the Principia. Wren had posed the same problem to Halley and Hooke earlier — it was a competitive race among mathematicians who socialised at the same London coffee-houses. Locke met Newton in 1689 and became one of his closest intellectual companions; his empiricism and Newton's physics formed a complementary assault on Cartesian rationalism. The Huguenot diaspora carried these ideas across Europe: refugees like Pierre Bayle (whose Dictionnaire would arm Voltaire) spread Lockean and Newtonian thinking through the Republic of Letters. What looked like separate events — a scientific treatise, a religious persecution, an architectural project, a political conspiracy — were all nodes in the same network of minds reshaping European thought.
conn.funFact: The Royal Society had just published Francis Willughby's lavishly illustrated Historia Piscium — a definitive book about fish. It sold so poorly that when Halley asked for funds to publish the Principia, the Society was broke. Halley paid from his own pocket. Fish nearly delayed the Scientific Revolution.

title: Sens — The Duel of Reason and Faith
teaser: At the Council of Sens, Bernard of Clairvaux prosecutes Peter Abelard for heresy — dialectics versus mysticism, logic versus devotion. Meanwhile, Abbot Suger raises walls of light at Saint-Denis, Gothic architecture is being born, and Gratian codifies canon law. The 12th-century Renaissance transforms how Europe thinks.

art.label: Art
art.content: At the Abbey of Saint-Denis near Paris, Abbot Suger (1081–1151) is transforming architecture. Between 1140 and 1144, he rebuilds the abbey choir using an unprecedented combination of pointed arches, ribbed vaults, and flying buttresses — structural innovations that distribute weight so efficiently that walls can become windows. "The dull mind rises to truth through material things," Suger writes, drawing on Pseudo-Dionysian theology: God is light, and architecture should be luminous. No one yet calls this style Gothic (that name comes later, as an insult), but what begins at Saint-Denis in these years will reshape the skyline of Europe — Chartres, Notre-Dame, Cologne — a forest of stone and glass reaching toward heaven.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Geoffrey of Monmouth (c. 1095–c. 1155) completed his Historia Regum Britanniae around 1136, and by 1141 it circulates widely, transforming European imagination. He claims to translate an ancient British source; in truth, he invents a mythology — King Arthur, Merlin, Excalibur, the passing to Avalon. His Arthur is not history but something more powerful: a shared dream that will be retold for a millennium. Courts will model themselves on Camelot; knights will seek Holy Grails. The 12th century discovers that humans are storytelling animals, and that myths carry truths history cannot. Simultaneously, Héloïse (c. 1101–1164) composes her letters and the Problemata — philosophical questions that challenged Abelard and influenced his ethics. Her correspondence becomes foundational to the epistolary tradition.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: At the Council of Sens in June 1141, Bernard of Clairvaux (1090–1153), the most powerful mystic in Christendom, prosecutes Peter Abelard (1079–1142) for heresy. Abelard's method — applying dialectical reasoning to theology, "by doubting we come to inquiry, by inquiry we perceive the truth" — horrifies Bernard: he treats the Trinity as a syllogism! Abelard walks out without defending himself, appeals to Rome, but Bernard's letters arrive first. The Pope condemns Abelard to perpetual silence. Yet Abelard's Sic et Non method — juxtaposing contradictory authorities to provoke resolution — will become the foundation of Scholasticism. The duel at Sens is between two ways of knowing: reason examining faith versus faith transcending reason.

hist.label: History
hist.content: In Bologna, the monk Gratian compiles the Decretum (c. 1140) — systematically reconciling centuries of contradictory church laws through the same dialectical method Abelard applied to theology. His work founds canon law as a science, governing marriage, property, crime, and clergy across Christendom for eight centuries. Meanwhile, students at Bologna study recovered Roman law; in Paris, cathedral schools transform into the universitas — corporations of scholars with legal rights. The 12th-century Renaissance is institutional as much as intellectual: knowledge is becoming systematic, professional, transmissible. Arabic translations of Aristotle flood into Paris through Toledo, bringing Greek logic recovered via Islamic scholarship.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: The tensions at Sens ripple through every domain. Bernard of Clairvaux was friends with Abbot Suger despite their theological differences — both advised King Louis VII, both shaped the Crusade ideology. Peter the Venerable, Abbot of Cluny, sheltered the condemned Abelard in his final months and brokered a reconciliation with Bernard. Gratian's Decretum uses the same sic et non method Abelard developed — contradictory sources dialectically resolved. Geoffrey of Monmouth's Arthur myths emerged from the same cathedral school culture in Oxford where dialectics was taught. The 12th-century Renaissance was a single conversation conducted in stone, law, logic, and legend — all grappling with what reason could know and what required faith.
conn.funFact: When Abelard died in 1142, Peter the Venerable sent his body to Héloïse. She buried him at the Paraclete; twenty-two years later, she was laid beside him. Their shared tomb remains in Paris's Père Lachaise Cemetery today.

title: Rome — The City of God
teaser: Rome falls. Augustine rises. The first philosophy of history is born from catastrophe.

art.label: Art
art.content: Late Antique Christian art is transforming the visual language of the Empire. Churches rise with elaborate mosaic programs — Santa Pudenziana in Rome (c. 400) shows Christ enthroned among apostles in a style that fuses Roman imperial imagery with Christian meaning. The poet Prudentius writes Dittochaeon, a series of quatrains designed as captions for church murals, bridging visual and literary culture. Meanwhile, his Psychomachia (c. 405) — the first full-scale personification allegory in Western literature — will inspire countless medieval manuscript illuminations of battling Virtues and Vices.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Jerome, working in Bethlehem, has nearly completed the Vulgate — his Latin translation of the Bible from Hebrew and Greek that will dominate Western Christianity for over a millennium. When news of Rome's fall reaches him, he writes: "The city which had taken the whole world was itself taken." Prudentius represents the apex of Christian Latin poetry, fusing classical forms with Christian content. His hymns remain in liturgical use today. Claudian, the last great pagan poet, had died just recently (c. 404), marking the literary end of classical tradition.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Augustine of Hippo begins De civitate Dei (The City of God) in direct response to the sack. Pagans blame Christianity for abandoning the old gods; Augustine responds with the first systematic Christian philosophy of history. He distinguishes the civitas Dei (heavenly city) from the civitas terrena (earthly city), arguing that Rome's fall matters little against eternity. This inaugurates Augustinian theology — his doctrines of original sin, divine grace, and predestination will shape Western thought for fifteen centuries. Neoplatonism, filtered through Porphyry and Plotinus, provides his philosophical framework.

hist.label: History
hist.content: On 24 August 410, Alaric I and the Visigoths sack Rome — the first time the city has fallen to a foreign enemy in 800 years. Though Rome had ceased to be the administrative capital (moved to Ravenna in 402), the psychological impact is immense. The Western Roman Empire will survive another 66 years, but the myth of Roma aeterna is shattered. Refugees flood North Africa, bringing tales of horror to Augustine's congregation in Hippo. The Migration Period accelerates — within decades, Vandals, Burgundians, and Franks will carve up the Western provinces.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Augustine's City of God is the philosophical response to what Jerome and Prudentius are living through emotionally and artistically. Jerome's Vulgate gives the Latin West a unified scriptural foundation just as political unity collapses — the Bible becomes the new binding text of a fragmented world. Prudentius's allegorical technique in the Psychomachia will merge with Augustine's two-cities framework to create medieval literature's obsession with moral combat. The sack forces a question that will define the next thousand years: if earthly Rome can fall, where does true permanence lie?
conn.funFact: The Visigoths sacked Rome for only three days. Alaric, an Arian Christian, ordered his troops to spare churches and those who took refuge in them — a mercy Augustine carefully noted in his defense of Christianity.
